content.raw: I added backticks to the output so it's easier to read. I can also repost the output if you prefer. Just let me know what's easiest.

content.raw:
Could you check the output of this command?

`rosparam get /robot_description`

Also, could you double check that you pull, update and recompile from the last version of `default`?
content.html:
Could you check the output of this command?

rosparam get /robot_description

Also, could you double check that you pull, update and recompile from the last version of default?

content.raw:
OK, I ran:

```
#!bash

hg up default
hg pull
catkin_make
roslaunch wamv_gazebo localization_example.launch
```
and got the same errors as above.
Then I ran:

```
#!bash

rosparam get /robot_description
```

and got:
```
ERROR: Parameter [/robot_description] is not set
```
content.html:
OK, I ran:

hg up default
hg pull
catkin_make
roslaunch wamv_gazebo localization_example.launch

and got the same errors as above. Then I ran:

rosparam get /robot_description

and got:

ERROR: Parameter [/robot_description] is not set

content.raw: I'm sure you probably have the latest code but you should run `hg pull` first, and then, `hg update`.
content.html: I'm sure you probably have the latest code but you should run hg pull first, and then, hg update.

content.raw: OK, I did that too. Still no robot_description parameter though.
content.html: OK, I did that too. Still no robot_description parameter though.

content.raw: Hmmm - are you running on a laptop?  Maybe you could bring it buy tomorrow and I could take a look?
content.html: Hmmm - are you running on a laptop? Maybe you could bring it buy tomorrow and I could take a look?

content.raw: The problem was that I didn't understand the relationship between the commands described in this tutorial. In particular, that Gazebo produces the simulated input needed by the robot_localization package, so the first command must continue to run for the second to work, and likewise both commands must be running for the third to work (since rviz is using the robot localization data). I've edited the instructions to suggest opening a new terminal so my fellow noobs are not tripped up by this.
content.html: The problem was that I didn't understand the relationship between the commands described in this tutorial. In particular, that Gazebo produces the simulated input needed by the robot_localization package, so the first command must continue to run for the second to work, and likewise both commands must be running for the third to work (since rviz is using the robot localization data). I've edited the instructions to suggest opening a new terminal so my fellow noobs are not tripped up by this.

content.raw: Tutorial is now running without errors.
